page.title: 15 THOMAS BROWN
page.content: Thomas Brown was born in Kirkleatham. He was an apprentice to a shoemaker and his father was a blacksmith. Whilst serving as a private in the King's Own Regiment of Dragoons he became one of Yarm's best heroes. During the Battle of Dettingen, in Bavaria on 27 June 1743, the standard was captured. In the midst of heavy fire Thomas bravely fought his way round and recovered it, although two balls got stuck in his back and three in his hat. He returned to Yarm and took over an inn, where he lived for three years. He died on 18 January 1746 and was buried in the parish churchyard. In 1908 the inn lost its licence and was renamed "Thomas Brown House". On 23rd March 1985 the band and horse of The Queen's Own Hussars visited Yarm in honour of their hero.
